ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: textbooks

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Learned basic Korean grammar and structures. Some vocabulary.
beginner-level Korean using the most common speaking level. as advanced as how to ask for directions and describing your day

This course not only introduced me to the Korean language, but also taught me 'how' I should approach learning a language. Through the various practices, such as Open Your Ears Wide, the Korean Workbook, and the various spoken presentations and assignments, I was able to quickly and effectively learn the basics of the Korean language. This course also taught me that I should spend consistent time learned the language everyday, and having class everyday was one step in the right direction.
An elementary understanding of the Korean alphabet and basic grammar.
A very good base knowledge of Korean, including a lot of vocab, grammar and multiple tenses.
I learned a lot of basic Korean and got to practice a lot.
Basic knowledge of how to read, write, and speak Korean.
Learnt a lot of introductory Korean.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
strengths: engaging content, diverse range of assignments, the professor
weaknesses: a lack of ways to practice Korean outside of class besides the TA (no language tables)

On of the biggest strengths of this course is the layout and resources of this course. The layout, specifically the other that the course is taught and the sequence of presentations and assignments, helps bolster the Korean language within the students mind. Starting from the basics and working our way up, with cumulative tests and quizzes, ensured our understanding and development of the Korean language.
Strong engagement, appropriate workload
I really enjoyed it, and I think it adapted really well to the virtual setting. Sometimes the multiple textbooks got me a little mixed up, but I would say it was exactly as I had hoped.
I liked that there is very little to prepare besides homework as Prof. Lim introduced all material in class. On the downside, the textbook could be a little better suited for independent study.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
succeeded: breakout rooms were good to practice without the pressure of the whole class
could be improved: opportunities to practice korean outside class
The class was well adapted to virtual learning

I think language courses, especially beginner ones, are some of the more successful courses overall to do online. The fact the class is daily, rigorous and has regular homework (not daily, but regular) means that it's relatively easy to fall into language-learning.
It's difficult to have speaking practice online, but I thought the breakout rooms were done well to facilitate conversation. Especially
The class was well adapted for online instruction.
The class worked surprisingly well. I believe we were able to get a good grip on pronunciation even through zoom.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Only take it if you're really, really interested in the material and have the time to put into learning the material well. The volume of work in this class is comparably high, even for a language course. Memorizing vocabulary was particularly difficult because there are few Korean-English cognates.

I took this as a way of exploring a completely new language outside of the Indo-European languages with which I was already familiar, and it was honestly hard to keep up with the heritage speakers who seem to like taking this class. Perhaps obviously, this class seemed to strongly favor those with prior knowledge of some East Asian language like Mandarin. 

The work isn't necessarily difficult, it's just time intensive. Exams and grading are fair.

The class wasn't terrible, but if I could go back in time, I wouldn't take it again. 

I think some of the students in the class took this for their first language credit, and this is not a practice I would recommend, especially if you're a non-heritage speaker. There are better organized and more enriching language credits to take in your early years here. If you're looking for language credit(s), consider our world-class French department. I've also heard great things about the Spanish department.
If you always wanted to take Korean, yes! This is also one of the less intensive L1 language classes offered at Yale, but you still learn so much!

Yes, I would most definitely recommend this course to another student. As this course is informative and well-structured, I believe that students would gain from this course, in addition to finding it enjoyable.
Yes, it was a great introduction.
Definitely! It's a great beginner course, you learn a lot but it's certainly not unmanageable. It's a challenging but great language too, with great faculty.
Definitely, it's a good introduction to Korean.

I would encourage anyone who is unsure about what language to take to consider taking Korean. Initially the language is daunting because of the new alphabet system, but once that is mastered (within the first few weeks) the language is actually fairly enjoyable to learn.
